docs.lead_paragraph: Using fertility drugs increases a woman's chances of getting pregnant, but the drugs should be used cautiously to avoid the possibility of multiple birth, said a study and an accompanying editorial in the current issue of The New England Journal of Medicine. The report was the first large, well-controlled study to ask and answer the question about whether using fertility drugs actually improved chances of pregnancy. Some doctors have suggested that conception would occur normally without drug treatment if couples patiently tried sexual intercourse, and some have suggested that other treatments without fertility drugs might work just as well.

headline.main: Largest Study Yet Rates Effectiveness of Fertility Treatments

docs.abstract: Study in New England Journal of Medicine finds fertility drugs increase woman's chances of getting pregnant, particularly when combined with uterine injections of sperm; study and accompanying editorial warn drugs should be used cautiously to avoid possibility of multiple birth, noting women who wait can ofter achieve good results without drugs (M)
docs.snippet: Using fertility drugs increases a woman's chances of getting pregnant, but the drugs should be used cautiously to avoid the possibility of multiple birth, said a study and an accompanying editorial in the current issue of The New England Journal of...

docs.lead_paragraph: The folks at Babycenter.com, which offers advice and products for expectant and new parents, want to help expectant parents answer one of life's most important questions: Will the birth of a baby interfere with a major sporting event? To avoid possible conflicts, the site's creators have conceived the Sports Event Conflict Catcher and Conception Blocker. Through the magic of databases, the site (www.babycenter.com/conflicts) allows parents to enter in the anticipated arrival date of their bundle of joy and determine which of 3,000 sporting events they are likely to miss as a result. Or, for a digital-age twist on the phrase ''planned parenthood,'' you can choose an event you do not want to miss, say, the National Rodeo Championships (Dec. 3-12, Las Vegas, Nev.), and the Birth and Labor Conflict Catcher will tell you that the week of Feb. 26 is one that requires contraception, not attempted conception.

headline.main: Making a Tough Choice: A Bowl Game or a Baby

docs.abstract: New Web site, Babycenter.com, offers Sports Event Conflict Catcher and Conception Blocker, which allows prospective parents to enter anticipated due date of their baby and determine which of 3,000 sporting events they are likely to miss as result; drawing (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: After surveying the body of scientific literature on lesbian health and holding workshops with researchers and clinicians, a panel of experts convened by the Institute of Medicine issued a report last week deploring the gaps in reliable information about lesbian health. The panel called for large-scale studies to counter rampant ''myths and misconceptions'' and to improve the quality of treatment lesbians are receiving. ''In the face of little empirical information, there are numerous beliefs and misconceptions about the health risks of lesbians that can affect their health outcome,'' said the report, called ''Lesbian Health: Current Assessment and Directions for the Future.''

headline.main: Fact, Fiction and the Health of Lesbians

docs.abstract: Panel of experts convened by Institute of Health issues report deploring gaps in reliable information about lesbian health (M)
